Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing with a message from my mentor, asking for an update on the project. At the same time, my granddaughter slid into the chair across from me, her eyes wide with uncertainty. “Grandma, how did you know what to do when everything in your life started changing?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I could see she needed reassurance, a steady hand to guide her through her confusion. But my mind kept drifting to the technical problem I hadn’t solved yet, the one I was supposed to report to my mentor. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my granddaughter expecting wisdom and calm, my mentor expecting honesty and progress. My heart ached to be fully present for her, to offer the comfort she sought, but anxiety gnawed at me, reminding me of my responsibility to communicate my struggles at work. I wanted to be the wise grandmother she needed, but also the reliable mentee my mentor counted on. The two roles pulled at me, each demanding my attention, and I sat there, torn, unsure which need to answer first.
